text: Lastly, after spending a little over an hour and most of that time waiting for our food to arrive the manager barked at us to leave to make room for another party that had been waiting for 25 minutes!

as appetizers, we ordered the zucchini flowers (rich savory) escargot-topped mushroom caps (mediocre).

the space is very comfortable - they don't rush you - you don't have a server holding your bill in their hand asking if you'd like anything else.

The ambience is diner-like and the wait staff is rushed, but at these prices, I can't complain.

To finish, the cost of the dinner was over-priced.

The overpriced ice cream is delicious but the service is atrocious - not only do I have to wait to be admitted into this ice cream joint, but the waiter is a snide, gruff man more suited to be a trucker than an ice cream shop server.
I drank beer, but I tried her apple martini, It was great not sour at all.
The staff is very friendly too~  Everything is wonderful about this place except for the bathroom.
My complaint was the service was not that good but the food made up for it.

My friend and I did have to wait a few minutes for a table, but only because Amanda Hesser (the new NY Times food critic) showed up and, obviously, needed a copious level of attention from the greetings staff.
The bill was surprisingly inexpensive considering we each had appetizers, an entree, dessert and drinks (alcoholic and non) we also had 3 rounds of shots for the entire table.
We were seated quickly (and had reservations, but they didnt seem to be absolutely necessary) and our waitress offered much insight into menu bests and worsts.
Mojitos were good and prices werent bad but sides should be included in price as portions are tiny.
For those who don't like that you have to make a reservation, to the restaurant's credit, this allows the restaurant to remain uncrowded and seat you immediately (at least this happened to my party).
We tried to place the order and the waiter had no clue what we wanted even though we pointed it out on the menu.
The calamari salad was great while the lamb ribs were fat, fattier and fattiest.
The owner and his sister make you feel like you've been invited over to their house for dinner.
Service was at best distracted, at worst disdainful, even though we came early with a reservation and are not food novices.
Orange Valve is probably the best bar that I've been to in a while.
The brunch entrees were shockingly overpriced, even for the area, and especially given the food quality.
You can undoubtedly get better food and service for the price at other places, but certainly not with those views!
Went here for a casual Sunday night dinner at 7:45pm; dinner was served at 10:15pm!
Food is served simply but quickly with a smile.
Sometimes I wish there were a bar to sit at and have a glass of wine, but on the other hand the lack of one allows the place a pleasant sit down sort of feel.

The menu of Afghani favorites includes mantoo, the spicy beef dumplings in yogurt sauce; chicken with walnuts and pomegranate juice; saffron-marinated filet mignon; grilled Cornish game hen; meat and fish kebabs in various combinations; and a number of vegetarian rice- and bean-based dishes.
one waiter couldn't remember what we had to drink and we were the only people in the place.
The place is plain as well: forget about Nobu-style ambiance, Bond-like music and bar, Next door Nobu good-looking crowds etc - just plain, got it?
go there and get really good food, just don't expect to get out of there quickly and when the server comes to your table ask for everything you'll be needing for the rest of the evening.
No compensatory nibbles or drinks were supplied -- even after we indicated to the waiter that it was 'the right thing to do'
Those of you who are sick of the standard Italian fare will be blown away by the food at Arezzo.
They have a lot of beautiful clientele, gay and straight, plus you#146;ll spot random famous actors on occasion.
Our server never bothered to inquire as to whether or not we wanted coffee.

I would feel different if we were just drinking water and eating cake but we had 20 people drinking multiple overpriced beverages AND one friend had called ahead of time to find out about the cake and no one ever picked up the phone.
As for the sides, the grits were more like soupy cheese sauce; the greens were okay.
Their new style of all you can eat is: They bring barely enough food for the table, mostly just bread ,until you ask a waiter to bring some more.
I said, that would be fine and had the hostess confirm my reservation before hanging up.

The only time the waitress paid any attention to us was when she took our order and at the end of our meal to ask if we wanted dessert (by then we had already packed up our leftovers and were waiting for change from our bill).
After reading other reviews I was expecting poor service and ambience but was pleasantly surprised by our more than helpful waiter.
At best, it's a mediocre restaurant, forget about the fish variety, I asked for Char (A sushi staple), and received a blank look from the waiter, same fish here as any grocery store.
We were so irritated about how horrible the food was, we didn't stick around to hangout at the bar.
The sushi was delicious and fresh and they didn't short you on the pieces of fish either.
The ambiance and service is great but I wish I could say the same about the food.
For breakfast there are a wide variety of whole grain pancakes; pumpkin is my favorite, blueberry second!
Olives served at the bar are wonderful.
For appetizer, I like Potli Samosa, but sometimes it is improperly cooked, which ruins the taste.
We were told by the front door hostess since we didn't have a reservation, it would be about 45mins for a table, but we could wait at the lounge and they would get us when our table was ready.

Waiter was very arrogant, though tha staff was attentive and when a waiter pilled a glass of water on one of our guests, the hostess ran with a dry cleaning voucher even though we did not make a big deak of it - just an accident and only water.
An order of roast chicken is nicely crisped and moist, although the potato cubes alongside are limp.
anyway, nice place for brunch for selection under $20 meals desserts were great (3 flavors for creme brulee!!
While there are now a few appetizers, the traditional thali (sampling platter) is often your best bet; fixed nightly menu changes daily.
The service and surroundings couldn't have been better, but the food was very disapointing at best.
And don't forget to try the Korean rice wine to go with your dinner (Sansachun is one of my favorite).
Service during dinner was alright, but one's perception to a restaurant usually starts from the very beginning: the entrance.
The place is very loud, good for drinks by the bar not to eat and yell.
I for one do not plan to go back, there are many other places in Manhattan that have just as good food if not better, at the same prices with much better service.
The Food In a less-than-booming economy, it's a joy to find an East Village bistro with entrees that rarely top 15 bucks.
Now residing in Chicago, the only quality pies are the deep dishes, which I do like.
Went with a large group of 7 ladies before a show, and the staff was extremely obliging, even when one person was late and we had to wrap up her dinner to take to her.
Our dinner party of four all found the food better than average and of sizeable portions.
They do have a large menu of things along the diner lines, and they go a little gourmet on the brunch omelette fixins/combos.
Man, that chicken (in some kind of spicy soup) was yummy!
the place was empty and the waiters just hung out at the bar.
The dinner special is amazing, although I would pick the meat option rather than seafood.
The waiter rushed us through the last half of our dinner because they were turning the room into a dance floor.
Or belly up to the beef belly soup, made with wide chow fun noodles and a thick, beefy broth.
the grain salad was ok, the calf liver was stringy and the roast onions that came with it too heavy.
Aside from that, the service is adequate (visible, and will help you if you ask, but lack initiative), and the food, well, could be a lot worse.
Not to mention that the busboy spilled 2 glasses of water on my back and the Manager was NOWHERE TO BE SEEN.
Waiter suggests a beer, and offers to bring a small glass, to taste it and see if I like it, before I even order the beer!
The Scene There are exactly three small tables at this tiny hole in the wall, but for food lovers on a budget, it's heaven.
If you want great Italian food, fairly price, good service, in Brooklyn, a couple of subway stops from Union Square,(where you should complain about the prices) go to Al Di La.
While we were trying to have dinner, all of the waiters spent their time playing with spilled milk at the counter, not paying any attention to the diners.
The waiter's recommendation for the entree (seabass in a lime and mango chutney) exceeded our expectations and we ate the chutney to the last drop.
The place was not crowded for dinner on a Sunday night at 8:30pm.
Don't let the ambiance of this place fool you, the food is far better than many pricey establishments.
Still, after all the fuss, the food makes you forget about the wait.
I ordered the strip steak medium - the waiter or the chef reversed our requests.
The Egg and Cheese on a bagel here is HUGE.
In the most beautiful ground floor brownstone setting.
I love deviled eggs, a BBQ staple - but I'll be damned if serving two eggs (four VERY small halves) qualifies as an appetizer.
Our waitress had a French accent and her caring and knowledgeable attitude she discplayed with each table led us to beleive she was the owner.
I highly suggest you make reservations, as wait times can be extremely long.
Dinner's nothing to scream about (although there are a few winners on the menu), but solid margaritas and appetizers are well-suited for a summer evening.
I have never had a bad meal or service (on a couple of occasions I waited past my reservation time).
Paul's frozen seafood and the other cuts of meat were disappointing, with the only acceptable appetizers being the corn chowder and the gravlax.
But then there's the sluggish and absentminded service: twice someone tried to serve us something for another table and it took a long time to get our check.
I went here all 4 years that I lived in the area, and being a not-so-loaded student, it was a great place to go for some good sushi and a very pleasant comforting atmosphere.
When I asked to speak to a manager, I was sent to voicemail, and I still haven't received a callback.
When we were finally seated about half an hour after my reservation, the waitress took her time taking our order.

We both orderd drinks that we never recived, but were charged for, and when we said something to the waiter he rolled his eyes and asked if we wanted them anyway (after we were done eating and more than ready to go.
Have the kitchen split as an appetizer its signature cheese and linguini pasta that is curled in a large round cheese bowl that look like a giant candle right at your table.
The entertainment is awesome - and believe it or not, I was so impressed with one of their musicians/singers (named Alessandro) that I even had him play during my cocktail hour.
we shared many dishes but none really stood out except the spinach, wow!!
worst margaritas in town,if you are going to order a battle of (white wine)they served hot.
The small shrimp were dry and rubbery and when I sent the dish back to the kitchen, the waitress returned saying that they use 'frozen shrimp so that is wny they have that texture.
I have lived in Japan for 7 years and the taste of the food and the feel of the restaurant is like being back in Japan.

A few years ago I would have rated it much higher, but now - with other better choices such as Candle Cafe, Good Health Cafe and others, the dated menu, crowded atmosphere are spacey service is not the greatest choice.
YYMV, we visited for Restaurant Week so the quality of the food may have been below normal standards because of the crowds.
Our waitress was so helpful with the wine list.
the atmosphere is that of a diner, but if you get a booth that is the best!
For brunch, go for the fluffy raisin challah French toast or Tex-Mex scrambled eggs with fresh tortillas and a side of crisp pork sausage.

text: The food was not gourmet fare it was perfectly fine burgers, salads and pasta.
For entrees, the Ground Lamb in Spicy Sauce (can't remember the name on the menu) was perfectly cooked and had just enough kick for the average person.
We were seated fastly enough, and ordering was painless, but I got the wrong appetizer, we both received the same item instead.
Faux Models/Waiters hustle around the tight spaced restaurant, while the bar is crowded with waiting patrons and dates enjoying a drink.
After having the table cleared and recieving fresh warm plates, we shared the Chicken Tikka Masala and the Chicken and Lentils.
The wait was not very long and the staff was great.

from the pad thai, pad see yu, to the duck dishes and of course to the ubiquitious thai tea and coffee, Rice delivers good quality, affordable and pretty darn authentic Thai food in a city known for fusing it with every other imaginable combination.
Sure, the hostess can be rude, but when in the mood for authentic Mexican food, there is no better place in NYC, yet.
